_prev_prog_3.Description: The Boar's Head Forrest City Arkansas facility is equipped to handle any accidental spills or releaseswith a fully equipped and trained HAZMAT team, the team members have all completed 40 hours of HAZWOPER training and we provide 8 hours of refresher training yearly. The HAZMAT team along with members of the Forrest City Fire Department underwent training on 11-03. The facility is equipped with ammonia detectors in critical areas that, in the event of a leak will trigger alarms in the refrigeration control room as well as the guardshack. The plant has practice evacuations semi annually and the Forrest City Fire Department has been in the plant on safety inspections and will be with the plant personnel in an emergency response situation. The Boar's Head Forrest City Arkansas facility has been in operation for eight years without a single toxic release or accident with the ammonia refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Boar's Head Provisions Co. Inc. operates a meat processing facility located at 2530 West Broadway Street Forrest City Arkansas, the plant employs 490 production and maintenance personnel distributed on three shifts. The facility uses Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) as a heat transfer media. Most of the facility is cooled to 35 to 40 degrees F in order to preserve the meat and meat products. The ammonia refrigeration system is computer controlled and the facility is manned 24 hours a day 7 days a week. The materials used in the covered process are of the highest quality and standards available to the refrigeration industry and the Boar's Head management and engineering team maintains that the contractors used to install and maintain the the ammonia refrigeration system meet the highest qualifications dictated by the P.S.M. standard. The facility has ammonia detectors located in strategic locations throughout the refrigeration system. The facility is operated under the P.S.M. standard and complys with all O.S.H.A. and federal as well as state and local codes and ordinances.

PROCESS TECHINICAL DESCRIPTION:
The refrigeration operates as a single stage ammonia refrigeration system @ 3:1 recirculation rate.
Defrost is achieved by utilizing hot gas taken from the compressor discharge header.
In the compressor room there are eleven (11) Frick rotary screw compressors which service the various air cooling evaporators throughout the facility as well as the glycol and water chillers. The ammonia is cooled utilizing eight (8) evapco evaporative condensers.

y the crops and at times they fly very close to the plant, since all of the ammonia refrigeration equipment is located inside of the equipment room except the condensers, a major release on one of them would be the worst off site impact.

The Boar's Head management team recognizes that safety and safety training are paramount to an environment of productivity and well being of the associates in our facilities as well as the surrounding community, we have on staff a full time safety coordinator and health care associates on production shifts.
We routinely train all of the associates on process safety as well as lockout tagout, hazcom and food safety. SECTION I - PLAN INTRODUCTION ELEMENTS



I. PURPOSE:  Boar's Head Provisions is a further processor of cut meats.  Due to the required temperatures that need to be maintained on a consistent basis, Boar's Head provision uses Anhydrous Ammonia as a refrigerant.  If ther

e is a release of Anhydrous Ammonia, any other hazardous chemical or oil, this plan will eliminate confusion for facility HAZMAT personnel.  The guidance is designed to yield a highly functional document for use in varied emergency situations and establish coordination between facility HAZMAT personnel and local, state and federal emergency response personnel.



II. SCOPE:    This Integrated Contingency Plan is intended to be used by Boar's Head Provision's to prepare Emergency Response Plans for responding to releases of highly hazardous substances.  The intent is to provide a mechanism for consolidating multiple plans that Boar's Head my have to comply with into one functional Emergency Response Plan or Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).  The Integrated Contingency Plan is also commonly referred to as the "One Plan".

SECTION II - CORE PLAN ELEMENTS



I.          DISCOVERY:  This section addresses the initial action the persons discovering an                         

             incident will take to assess the problem at hand and access the response system.



A. If an associate or manager/supervisor identifies an emergency situation, they must contact the nearest supervisor or manager in the area.  He or she will give the location and a brief description of the emergency problem.  The Supervisor or Manager will investigate the reported emergency problem and will determine if the Integrated Contingency Plan needs to be activated.  The Supervisor or Manager will then notify the guardhouse of the situation and give the predetermined codes.  Depending on the situation and its severity, the guard on duty will notify the Plant Manager.  The Plant Manager will make the decision on what type of evacuation should take place (total or partial).  When complexity so indicates, the HAZMAT team will be notified.



II. INITIAL RESPONSE:



A. PROCEDURES FOR INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS:



1. Once the severity of the situation is determined, the HAZMAT team shall be notified.  The Safety Officer will contact the Incident Commander and the Refrigeration Supervisor and a determination will be made on whether the emergency response management system needs to be established.



2. The guardhouse will contact the proper outside emergency services.  These organizations include:



a. Fire department - Police - Hospital:  911

b. St. Francis County Rescue Squad - 911

c. St. Francis County Sheriff's Office - 911



3. The Safety Coordinator, Incident Commander or the Refrigeration Supervisor will be responsible for contacting the National Response Center at (800) 424-8802 and the Arkansas Department of Emergency Management at (501) 730-9751 or (800) 322-4012. 



4. The guardhouse will also contact the proper persons internally.  These individuals include:



a. Mike Locke - Plant Manager:  Ext. 4132



b.     Dwaine Dierksen - Refrigeration Supervisor: Ext. 4175

                                                     Pager # - 1-800- 678-9053

                       Cell # -  870-270-0872   or  1-417-818-3093   

b. Eric Trimble - Maintenance Supervisor:  Ext. 4121  

                                                     Pager # -  1-866-283-7762  

c. John Campbell - Corporate Safety, Health and Environmental Manager

Office (804) 733-7100 ext. 3146

Home (804) 733-5983

d. Edward A. Spafford - Corporate PSM/RMP Coordinator

Office (804) 733-7100  Ext. 3180

Home (804) 265-5308



B. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM:



1. The Plant Manager has the responsibility and authority for the organization, direction and coordination of all activities, including assistance by outside parties, to cope with chemical release emergencies or oil spills that may occur.



2. The readily available HAZMAT technician will assume incident command and assign safety, medical, entry team, decon and backup team officers until relieved by higher authority.  The Incident Commander and Safety Officer will establish the incident command center in the guard shack or Maintenance office as applicable.



3. The Incident Commander will determine actions to be taken and assist or direct, as required, responding emergency personnel, Security, safety, Medical, Entry, Backup and Maintenance.  It shall be noted here that the Maintenance supervisor is on the HAZMAT team and will be a critical contact for the Incident Commander.



4. The Safety Officer will a

ssist the Incident commander in his duties and will also be Liaison officer.  His responsibilities will include the following:



a. Will not authorize entry into the hot zone until Decon is set up.



b. Will monitor all communications of emergency responders in the hot zone.



c. Has the authority to terminate response activities if proper safety practices are not followed.



d. Will measure and record vital signs.  Any responders that may have high vital signs will be asked not to suit up but assist with incident command.  This particular individual may even be assigned Decon officer.



e. Will report injuries to the ICC and notify supporting emergency medical services when directed.



f. Will measure and record vital signs of emergency responders after return form the hot zone and initiate further monitoring or treatment as necessary



g. Can downgrade the level of protection based on Sensidyne pump readings in the hot zone.  



5. The Plant Manager or other designated individual will act as the public information officer.  He/she will be responsible for contact with the press and civil authorities.  He will be responsible for all release information.  All critical information shall be given to him in the press release form.







C. ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INCIDENT COMMAND CENTER:

 

1. Upon initial notification by Supervisors other Emergency Response personnel of a suspected chemical release, the Incident Commander, Safety Officer and other Emergency Response Officers will form the Incident Command Center in accordance to the direction of the wind.



2. Upon formation of the ICC, the Incident Commander will dispatch two members of the Emergency Response Team to the release area with Level A hazardous response equipment:



a. Totally Encapsulated Suit



b. Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA)



c. Sensidyne pump and ammonia detection tubes or appropriate detection tubes.



d. Radio communications ability.



D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES: 



1

. Upon notification that a suspected release has occurred, the Incident Commander will perform the following tasks:



a. Establish the Incident Command Center.



b. Restrict movement of all personnel throughout the area surrounding the hot zone.



c. Identify the hot, warm and safe zones.



d. Dispatch the Emergency Responders to the area for investigation.

 

e. Establish a decontamination area.



f. Instruct Responding personnel to cut the flow of hazardous chemicals to the hot zone.  The Refrigeration Supervisor or Lead Person will be a critical contact for this procedure.



g. Instruct Responding personnel to turn off all electrical power feeding the hot zone if necessary.  The Maintenance Supervisor will be a critical contact for this procedure.  It shall be noted that the Refrigeration Supervisor is a qualified electrician and can provide input on this procedure if the Maintenance Supervisor is not present.



h. Entry Team and Backup team will suit up and report time on breathing air.



* Sensidyne pump readings will be taken at the perimeter of the hot zone, midpoint and in the release area at a minimum.  The ICC should be notified of each reading by radio.



* Make an assessment of the release area and notify the ICC of damage and the scope of the release.  They shall also inform the ICC if the release is local or an area release.  A localized release is a release that is confined to problem area.  An area release is a release that has spread to surrounding areas other than the problem area.



* Report findings to the ICC or return to the entry point for further instructions.



* The entry team will make necessary repairs or return to the entry point for necessary tools.



* The entry team will re-enter the hot zone and make the necessary repairs.  If the entry team has exhausted their breathing air cylinders to the point that re-entry could endanger their livelihood, then the backup team will enter the established hot zone.



* If the backup t

eam is not required to enter the hot zone, they will remain on stand by at the entrance to the hot zone and assist the entry team in the case of an emergency.



i. Other Emergency responders will standby at the ICC and will receive instructions from the Incident Commander.



j. If the release is of major proportions and uncontrollable as determined by the Incident Commander and Safety Officer, only the following steps will be taken:



* Cut the flow of the chemical to the area if this procedure has not yet been already performed.



* Cut the power to the area.



* Evacuate all personnel from the area.



* Contact the Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality (501) 682-0713



* Contact the Arkansas Department of Emergency Management (800) 322-4012



* Contact the EPA national response hotline. (800) 424-8802



E. RESPONSE DURING NIGHTS OR WEEKENDS:



1. The refrigeration mechanic on duty or the senior-trained management employee will assume Incident Command until relieved by a higher authority.  It shall be noted here that HAZMAT training is still not complete for those individuals who are required to have.  If complexity so indicates, then the security guard on duty shall refer to Section II.A.3.a above.



F. ESTABLISHMENT OF A DECONTAMINATION STATION:



1. All persons entering the hot zone will be decontaminated upon re-entering the warm zone.  This will be done utilizing the procedures listed below.  The decontamination area will be located immediately outside and upwind from the hot zone.



a. Decontamination team will wear proper personal protective equipment.



2. Decontamination team will wash down all persons exiting the hot zone using medium pressure, warm water using a minimum of the following three stations:



a. Station 1: Employee will step into a footbath and follow instructions of the decontamination team.  The first step is a dry brush down to remove gross contamination and an inspection of the employees' protective suit.  Employee w

ill be asked about air supply or other problem.  Decontamination team will use a mild detergent and water solution to wash off the surface of the suit.



b. Employee will step into the second footbath where his suit will be rinsed off.  This will be the third station



c. Employee will enter the third station where his protective gear will be pealed off.  The respirator will be the final item of gear removed.



d. Vital signs of the employee will be monitored and further medical monitoring may be recommended.



3. Emergency decontamination will consist of removal of gross contamination and washing the injured employee to remove contamination to a point where it is safe to begin emergency medical treatment.  Further decontamination will be done as possible.  



4. The ICC will be debriefed and any necessary cleanup will begin.





G. PROCEDURES FOR PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT OF THE SITUATION:



1. After the initial phase of the emergency response system has been established, the safety officer and the incident commander will work hand in hand in assessing the situation using MSDS books, and other available resources.  The Safety Officer and Incident Commander will then identify the hazards involved, the magnitude of the problem and resources threatened.  Based on this information, he will make the determination and place a priority on the situation and make the determination if HAZMAT personnel should continue emergency operations or abort operations.



 H.  PROCEDURES FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF OBJECTIVES AND                       

       PIORITIES FOR RESPONSE



1. Immediate goals/tactical planning:



a.   The immediate goal in specific incident is assuring the safety and health of     

BH employees and rendering aid to those in need. It is also the goal of the BH HAZMAT to control the situation and clear up the contaminated area before it harms the environment and the well being of the Forrest City / St. Francis Co. communities.                                                              

2. Mitigating a

ctions



a.   Depending on the situation at hand, it is the total responsibility of the           

HAZMAT team to take full control of the incident and recover any hazardous material that may be detrimental to the public and the surrounding environment.



b. The BH HAZMAT team will use the equipment provided for containment recovery and team safety.  They will use absorbent material to recover any lost contaminant and dispose of it in accordance to federal, state and local laws in order to prevent any contamination of the surrounding environment.  BH HAZMAT will have a decontamination area after the incident is under control to wash down any contaminated equipment.  Measures will be taken to dispose of decon material in accordance to Federal, State and Local laws.



c. Mitigating actions must be tailored to the type of hazard present.  If there is an oil or a chemical spill, the following steps shall be taken:



* Assessment of the situation by the incident commander and the safety coordinator using the appropriate resources.

* Action must be taken to direct flow away from storm drains and tributaries.  It is a goal of BH HAZMAT personnel to prevent any contamination to the surrounding environment.

* If there is a chemical spill involving two or more highly reactive chemicals, extreme care should be taken in order to ensure safety of BH HAZMAT personnel.

* If the situation becomes immediately dangerous to life and health, the situation shall be aborted.



--If there is an anhydrous ammonia release, the following steps and actions shall be taken:



* Assessment of the situation by the incident commander and the safety officer using the appropriate resources.  These resources shall include the use of the Sensidyne pump, detection tubes and the Passport Monitor.

* Identification of all forms of resources that will be needed.

* Action should be taken by the refrigeration mechanic on duty to close all valves that may feed the affected area after contacting th

e Refrigeration Supervisor or Utilities Manager.  If procedure has not been completed, then the entry team shall take control of the situation and close all valves leading to the affected area.

* Action must be taken to direct flow away from storm drains and tributaries.  It is a goal of BH HAZMAT personnel to prevent any contamination to the surrounding environment.



3. Identification of resources required for response



a. Depending on the incident, different measures will be taken.  All resources needed for response to any type of incident will be available.  In the event the incident can not be prioritized and the resources required for response can not be identified, air monitoring shall be performed to determine oxygen levels in an emergency situation.  Based on this monitoring, a decision can be made on the resources needed.



1. PROCEDURES FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF TACTICAL PLAN



1. The guardhouse will acknowledge the incoming call from a supervisor or manager and alert them to the situation. 



2. The guardhouse will then contact the plant manager so determination can be made on the evacuation measures.



3. Once the alarm has been activated and evacuation is complete, maintenance personnel will remain behind to monitor essential plant operations.  The severity of the situation will determine whether all these actions will be carried out.  Maintenance personnel will not be asked to enter an atmosphere or situation that may be immediately dangerous to life and health.



4. Dependent upon the severity of the situation, HAZMAT personnel will be notified.            

5. Upon arrival of HAZMAT personnel, an incident command post will assemble in accordance to the direction of the windsocks.

  

6. An entry team backup will be established.



7. The Incident Commander and Safety Officer will work hand in hand in assessing the situation and using the appropriate resources to determine the priority of the situation.  Upon entering, all HAZMAT personnel will use the

"buddy system" to ensure each other's safety.



8. Upon identification and prioritizing of the situation, the entry team shall use the appropriate resources to contain the affected are and control the incident.



9. Once the situation has been controlled and contained, cleanup procedures shall follow.  All absorbent material shall be disposed of properly in accordance to federal, state and local laws.

 

10. Once cleanup is complete, all entry team personnel and their equipment will go through the decon station.





F. PROCEDURES FOR MOBILIZATION OF RESOURCES



1. All equipment and resources are stored in the Boar's Head special operations trailer.  The company truck or an appropriate vehicle will transport the trailer within an established safe zone to allow for equipment setup.  This will be the established Incident Command Post.



III. SUSTAINED ACTIONS



A. The transition from the initial emergency stage and the response stage shall be smooth.  Most incidents shall be handled by only a few individuals without an extensive response management system.  It shall be the responsibility of security to maintain crowd and press control. There shall not be any interference with BH HAZMAT operations.



IV. INCIDENT TERMINATION AND FOLLOW UP



A. The incident commander and safety officer shall work hand in hand to terminate the response if complexity indicates.  If the incident is under control, then proper cleanup procedures shall be implemented in response to federal, local and state laws.



B. In the event the incident worsens and it may be immediately dangerous to life and health of the HAZMAT personnel, the Incident Commander and Safety Officer shall be able to recognize this situation and abort operations.  The above criteria shall be in coordination with the Federal or State on Scene Coordinator as necessary.



C. Follow up actions will be taken after termination of the operation.  These actions shall include:



1. Incident Investigation to determine wha

t caused the accident and the contributing factors leading up to the incident.



2. A written critique on the total response, which shall include, but not be limited to the following: Wind direction, identification of chemicals involved, the time it took for setup of operations and dressing out. How many team members made entry, how long it took them to control the situation, how long each member was in the hot zone and how long it took for cleanup operations and decon.





3. A review of the response plan to help make the determination on what areas need improvement, equipment inadequacies and purchases that need to be made what resources were used and if there were any problems complying with Federal, State and local laws.



4. A follow up report shall be written and shall address the above criteria.  The appropriate annexes will be referenced.



SECTION III - ANNEXES



ANNEX I. FACILITY AND LOCATION INFORMATION



A. Refer to Section 1.V.A-G



B. There are several nearby businesses that in the event of an ammonia release would be affected. 



C. Sensitive environments and populations:



1. Wild Life

2. St. Francis River

3. Farm Land

4. Local businesses                                        

ANNEX 2. NOTIFICATION



A. Internal/External Notification:



1. In case of an emergecny, associates should contact the nearest supervisor or manager in the area.  He or she will give the location and brief description of the emergency problem.



2. The supervisor or manager will investigate the reported emergency problem and will determine if the Integrated Contingency Plan needs to be activated.  The decision will be made to determine the type of evacuation (total or partial) by the plant manager.  The supervisor or manager will call the guardhouse (ext. 4161) and will give their name and predetermined codes, They will advise the security guard on the location and a brief description of the emergency problem.  They will then request that the emergency alarm be activated.



3. The Security

guard will activate the alarm to notify plant personnel.  He/She will also contact the receptionist so she can notify all office personnel.



4. It will be the responsibility of security with the assistance of the receptionist, to notify all outside emergency services.



5. The Arkansas Department of Emergency Management shall be contacted to reference what agencies should be notified.  That number is (501) 730 - 9751 or (800) 322-4012.  See Section 2.II.A.3 above.  Call list can be found in the core plan.



ANNEX 3. RESPONSE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM



A. GENERAL - TEAM MEMBER RESPONSIBILITIES



1. Incident Commander



a. Assess incident priorities

b. Determines strategic goals and tactical objectives

c. Develops/approves action plans

d. Develops command structure to meet the needs of the incident

e. Assess resource needs

f. Coordinates overall activities

g. Ultimate Safety Officer

h. Authorizes information release



2. Safety Officer



a. Assist Incident Commander of his duties.

b. Identify chemical and the incompatibilities.

c. Monitor Wind Direction.

d. Liaison Officer - Logs time and events of emergency response.

e. Ongoing assessment of the emergency situation.



3. Entry Team



a. Offensive operations.

b. Plugging and patching.

c. Controlling the spill and stopping release.



4. Entry Team (Back up)



a. Assist the initial entry team

b. Offensive operations

c. Plugging and patching 

d. Controlling the spill and stopping release.

 

B. UNIFIED COMMAND



1. In the event there is a need for help form local authorities, the proper steps shall be taken to inform them on how far along the response efforts have proceeded.  The incident commander shall relay the following information:



a. Chemical identity and the hazards associated with it.



b. Total response time at that moment.



c. The actual cause of the incident.



d. The number of BH HAZMAT personnel in the hot zone.



e. The direction of the wind.



f. What equipment is availabl

e.                                

g. And the exasperated resources.



* Upon recieval of this information, the responding service shall assist BH HAZMAT personnel in their attempt to control the situation.  The Forrest City Fire Department will assist BH security personnel on securing the scene.  They will assist in the HAZMAT response if needed.





       

C. COMMAND 



1. The Facility Incident Commander will be established based on the most senior-trained HAZMAT technician until released by a higher authority.



2. The incident commander has the responsibility to assess incident priorities and determine strategic goals and tactical objectives to take control of any situations.  He develops command structure to meet the needs of the incident and determines what resources are needed.  The Incident Commander coordinates all activities.  The Plant manager has overall authority to release information to the public and press.  He must receive a formal copy of all information from the Incident Commander and the established Safety Officer.



3. Command post shall be designated in accordance to the direction of the wind.



B. INFORMATION (internal and external communication)



1. Facility employees will be informed of the situation when plant evacuation has occurred.  They will not be given detailed information concerning the emergency.  BH does not want any false information circulating among the general public and the press.



2. The public will be notified by local and state authorities in the event the emergency situation is severe enough where this procedure is deemed necessary.



3. The plant manager or his designee will have the authority in addressing the press and coordination with the news media.  In case of fatalities, for confidential reasons, names of victims will not be disclosed until family members of the victim have been notified and verify release of this information.



C. SAFETY



1. In the event of an emergency, the incident commander and safety officer shall as

sess the scene to determine chemical identification and any possible incapabilities of the surrounding environment that may cause a more severe situation.  Upon this assessment and based on the information provided, the incident commander shall place a priority on the situation.  If the situation is deemed too severe than BH HAZMAT personnel will to be called upon to act.



2. HAZMAT members will not be permitted to enter the without using the buddy system.  The buddy system means organizing employees into work groups in such a manner that each member is observed by one of the members on the HAZMAT team.  Failure to use the buddy system could be costly.  The purpose of the buddy system is to provide rapid assistance to employees in the event of an emergency.



3. Decontamination setup



a. This is the station where removal of hazardous substances from HAZMAT personnel is performed.  All equipment and tools must pass through the decon station.  The purpose of decon is to preclude the occurrence of any foreseeable adverse health effects.



4. A Health Hazard means a chemical, mixture of chemicals or a pathogen for  which there is statistically significant evidence based on at least one study conducted in accordance with established scientific principles that acute or chronic health effects may occur in exposed team members.



5. HAZMAT personnel shall heavily monitor the hot zone upon entrance until the incident is deemed to be a highly hazardous situation and endangers personnel.  When the determination is made that response is too risky, responding personnel will be asked to abort operations



6. Facility personnel will be able to respond to an emergency alarm and will be provided with an easily accessible evacuation route.  Medically trained personnel will be available to render aid to those associates who may need it.  An outside emergency medical service authority will be on scene as well.  In the event that the priority of the emergency situation presents

a greater danger, all plant personnel will be asked to leave BH property for their own personal safety.



D. STAFF MOBILIZATION - LIASON



1. In the event of an emergency situation, there may be a need for outside assistance.  BH HAZMAT team and the Forrest City Fire Department will work together depending on the severity of the situation.  Upon arrival to the scene, the Forrest City Fire Department will be briefed on the situation at hand, the hazards that are being dealt with, the dangers these hazards pose to human life, what actions and offensive moves that have been tried, physical data concerning the environment and how long the situation has been combated.  The Fire Department will be told what actions need to be taken and will be made aware of what resources are still available.  They will be informed on what consist of the hot, warm and cold zone.  The goal here is to establish a unified command so the well being of the general public and the environment is not threatened.



E. OPERATIONS



1. Operational Response Objectives



a. Depending on the emergency situation at hand (ammonia release, chemical or oil spill) it will be the universal goal of BH HAZMAT personnel to obtain complete and total control of the situation.  This may or may not require the need for assistance from outside sources.    



2. Discharge or Release Control



a. BH HAZMAT personnel will use the resources on hand to contain the chemical spill, oil spill or ammonia release.  This includes the use of absorbent material and diking procedures to prevent contamination in the surrounding environment.



b. BH HAZMAT personnel shall consist of refrigeration technicians knowledgeable of all workstations and their locations.  This is critical when closing off valves and pipes that affect the immediate area.  The primary goal here is to isolate the affected area.



3. Assessment and monitoring



a. The safety officer and the Incident Commander will do assessment and monitoring on a contin

ual basis throughout the response.  The entry team will enter the hot zone and monitor the oxygen levels and.  With the use of ammonia detection tubes, a determination shall be made on the PPM concentration.  This information will be communicated to the incident commander and safety officer if the response shall be terminated.

                             

4. Containment



a. As before mentioned, BH HAZMAT personnel will work hand in hand to contain or dike any release or spill and prevent it form being discharged or released into storm drains or tributaries draining from Boar's Head Property.



5. Recovery



a. It will be a primary goal of BH HAZMAT personnel to recover as much contaminant as possible.



6. Decontamination



a. All persons entering the hot zone will be decontaminated upon re-entering the warm zone.  This will be done utilizing the procedures listed below.  The decon area will be located immediately outside and upwind from the hot zone.



b. The decon team will wear proper personal protective equipment.



c. The decon team will wash down all persons entering the hot zone using medium, warm water.



d. Emergency decontamination will consist of removal of gross contamination and washing the injured employee to remove contamination.  The employee will be moved to an area where it is safe to begin emergency medical treatment.  Further decontamination will be done as soon as possible.

  

e. The Incident command center will be debriefed and any necessary cleanup will begin.



7. Non responder medical needs (plant associates)



a. Medical attention shall be rendered by the plant and responding Emergency Medical Services if needed for those individuals that are not members of the HAZMAT team.

employers in making decisions for improving and reducing the chances of a catastrophic release of Anhydrous Ammonia.  A catastrophic release is a release that proves to be fatal to several people.  The PHA team came up with the following hazard using the Risk Matrix system.
